thread.section_title: Slate Magazine - Politics, Business, Technology, and the Arts
thread.title: Something Is Infecting Memes on X. It’s More Nefarious Than You Think.
thread.title_full: Something Is Infecting Memes on X. It’s More Nefarious Than You Think.

author: Owen Carry
title: Something Is Infecting Memes on X. It’s More Nefarious Than You Think.
text:
If you’ve been on X lately, you’ve probably seen this but not even realized it: a clean-looking logo for an online crypto casino called Stake pasted onto a [poorly cropped](https://x.com/ylevi/status/1845857153757712413) and [low-res](https://x.com/PercThaGoat/status/1837586316596310485) meme or a video.
Founded in 2017 by Australian entrepreneurs Ed Craven and Bijan Tehrani (but [ostensibly operated out of the small Caribbean nation of Curaçao](https://www.smh.com.au/business/markets/the-secret-australian-origins-of-the-world-s-biggest-crypto-casino-20211208-p59ftb.html)), Stake is a crypto gambling site worth more than $2.6 billion today. The company’s [most recent blog](https://stake.com/blog/september-casino-sports-betting-highlights-stats) post claims that over 1.2 billion bets were placed in September alone, and the [Financial Times reported](https://www.ft.com/content/2490279b-9c94-49a8-beff-cbd7c3307586) in 2023 that the company had roughly 600,000 regular users with 6 million registered accounts. Despite this, public perception of the site [seems overwhelmingly negative](https://www.smh.com.au/business/markets/the-secret-australian-origins-of-the-world-s-biggest-crypto-casino-20211208-p59ftb.html)—and much of its bad reputation comes from the viral marketing ploys the company uses to reel in new users.
Its new watermarking scheme on X is an amorphous advertising campaign that ignores international borders and the gambling laws that exist within them. While it’s legally sketchy, it’s also morally dubious. Kids who just want to look at memes have become the targets of a casino’s ruse.
The company has a history of strange marketing gimmicks. In 2022, many Twitch streamers like [Canadian star xQc](https://www.forbes.com/sites/mattcraig/2023/07/15/kick-vs-twitch-inside-streamings-billion-dollar-death-match-xqc-amouranth-ed-craven-stake/?sh=5e12638e129f) were offered what seemed like an [infinite money glitch](https://slate.com/technology/2024/09/chase-atm-money-glitch-viral-tiktok-trend-fraud.html) to gamble freely on Stake as long as they streamed their slot binges, blackjack games, and [mini-games such as Plinko](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jGYk8iSwehM) while live; xQc [reportedly bet an estimated $685 million](https://gamerant.com/twitch-xqc-gambling-streams-half-billion-dollars-wagers/) on the site with the company’s help. This added to [Twitch’s eventual decision to ban Stake](https://safety.twitch.tv/s/article/Prohibiting-Unsafe-Slots-Roulette-and-Dice-Gambling-Sites?language=en_US#:~:text=As%20such%2C%20starting%20October%2018th,periods%2C%20and%20age%20verification%20systems.) (among other gambling sites) from its platform soon after, citing the effects on its highly impressionable audience of Gen Z and Gen Alpha.
In response, Craven and Tehrani created Kick, a competitor streaming site, and tempted Twitch streamers with massive contracts to hop platforms and gamble freely. Now, more than a year later, xQc has reportedly bet [more than $2.9 billion](https://www.sportskeeda.com/us/streamers/news-xqc-reveals-wagered-2-9-billion-gambling-stake) on Stake while livestreaming on Kick. (He’s openly admitted to having [a gambling addiction](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0H0rpa66zCE) in the past.) Stake may be shameless about using its Kick stars to promote gambling, but its marketing strategies are not isolated to their Twitch knockoff.
Stake and Kick thus work in tandem, generating a slew of free marketing that spreads well outside their sites’ limits. But Stake’s latest tactic involves paying X accounts to watermark its logo on any and all posts they make.
Let’s say you make a meme, and you post it on your Instagram. It gets screenshotted and reposted by casual meme spreaders. Eventually, there’s a chance it winds up in the photo gallery of a Stake employee, where your content becomes an ad for the company. Nothing is removed. Only a logo is added. It’s then posted by an X account which has Stake tagged in its bio. It goes viral, giving the company tons of eyeballs on their logo. Rinse and repeat.
Patient zero for this ad experiment [appears to be](https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/stake-ads-on-twitter-x) X user [@FearedBuck](https://x.com/FearedBuck), who started as a Milwaukee Bucks fan account but later pivoted to posting Kick clips full time. In August, Stake logos [began showing up](https://x.com/FearedBuck/status/1820905715562692949) on the account’s videos. The page has since amassed more than 645,000 followers—up from [64,000 last December](https://archive.ph/Z1OBQ).
Viewers, [seemingly tired](https://x.com/HUN2R/status/1821335625926099265) of the account’s engagement-baiting antics and appalled by the obvious money grab, [Community Noted](https://x.com/i/birdwatch/n/1821553142112153832) all of @FearedBuck’s Stake-sponsored posts, explaining that the user was violating X’s guidelines on undisclosed promotions as well as violating the [Federal Trade Commission’s guidelines](https://www.ftc.gov/business-guidance/resources/disclosures-101-social-media-influencers) on gambling advertisements.
As quickly as it started, @FearedBuck went full-stop on the Stake logos. But other accounts have since stepped in, all of which mostly post Kick clips. The only thing that’s changed is that the Stake watermarks now have clarifying text, often reading “[Gamble Responsibly](https://x.com/picsthatg0hard_/status/1841577646100013388)” or “[This Is An #Ad](https://x.com/CFC_Janty/status/1827428302593589495),” in addition.
The additional declaration may swerve X’s guidelines but it doesn’t bypass the U.K.’s Advertising Standards Authority, which has [reportedly begun monitoring](https://insidersport.com/2024/10/11/asa-stake-watermarks-social-media/) Stake’s X campaign. The ASA has[ already taken action](https://insidersport.com/2023/10/18/sky-bet-neville-gaming-advertising/) against Sky Bet (a similar gambling site) from when ex-footballer Gary Neville watermarked the Sky Bet logo in a video.
Stake has landed in hot water for its advertising before. Back in August, the Dutch Gaming Authority [ordered the removal](https://insidersport.com/2024/08/21/formula-one-ordered-to-remove-stake/) of Stake logos from its sponsored Formula 1 cars, again citing influence on minors. Stake is not legal in the Netherlands and the ads (on a car, being televised) could not simply be geoblocked based on a user’s IP address.
Now they’ve made the jump to sponsoring meme pages, believing they can take the same tack: plaster your company logo on everything—like a player’s jersey or a stadium wall—and let the constant exposure become brand awareness. But memes and internet chatter are inherently organic and communal, which makes it much more egregious when they try this approach.
Take [this one](https://x.com/PercThaGoat/status/1841603758985195639) between two X accounts, [@PercThaGoat](https://x.com/PercThaGoat) and [@KillaMinga](https://x.com/KillaMinga), that both have Stake tagged in their bios. The latter shared a video of artwork with a Stake watermark. The subsequent quote tweet attested, “Average coworker phone wallpaper,” receiving over 28,000 likes.
The only problem: This is an elaborate two-part copycat that blatantly plagiarized the exact contents of [earlier X posts that happened](https://x.com/sparrows_honor/status/1741313879425053026) months before. The copycat post banks on the proven virality of its parts and the fact that many users haven’t seen the original posts yet.
Ever since Elon Musk [instated Twitter Blue](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/24/technology/elon-musk-twitter-blue.html), money grabs from blue-check accounts have become commonplace. A [“rent due” tweet](https://x.com/gayest_tone/status/1753168070372159622) has [become an axiom](https://x.com/byetyler/status/1848472819358654698) explaining the constant lewd shock-and-outrage bait that floods most of the timeline. To combat the onslaught, the site’s Community Notes feature acts as the law—but it’s an illusion of control. Individuals like @FearedBuck may have stopped posting Stake ads, but their original promotional posts [were never removed](https://x.com/FearedBuck/status/1820944327989690701) from the site entirely.
It’s well-known that [Musk is struggling with advertisers](https://variety.com/2023/digital/news/elon-musk-x-twitter-advertisers-antisemitic-post-spending-go-f-yourself-1235813657/), and although he’s promised to [remove the bots](https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2023/10/elon-musk-bots-x-users-have-to-foot-the-bill), he’s seemingly too addicted to the site’s engagement numbers to fully delete anything that’s going viral (unless [it challenges his right-wing dogma](https://x.com/esjesjesj/status/1845523107978830035)). While we can’t say that Stake is paying off Twitter, it’s obvious that Twitter’s turning a blind eye.
Another more drastic solution would be for the government to step in and do something about it. Stake is illegal in America. To work around this, Stake created [Stake.us](http://stake.us), which operates as a sweepstakes casino, meaning there’s no real money being bet. It’s all pretend money (tokens), and when an American opens the Stake homepage, it urges them to redirect to its legal stateside alternative where no real money can be wagered.
Because of this redirection, Stake has managed to abide by the FTC’s guidelines. However, if one views memes as a piece of media with disproportionately high influence on young minds, then the legality of Stake’s watermark campaign is much more murky.
This all depends on the viewpoint of FTC Chair Lina Khan, who is reportedly [more anti-business than many Democratic Party donors are comfortable with](https://www.wired.com/story/ftc-chair-lina-khans-democrats-donors-harris/). However, in an upcoming Trump presidency, the new FTC elect will likely be from the same talent pool as an [axe-throwing Fox News hos](https://www.tmz.com/2024/11/13/pete-hegseth-hits-bystander-with-axe-resurfaced-fox-news-clip/)t or even [Elon Musk himself](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2024/nov/12/trump-appoints-elon-musk-government-efficiency-department). With a Stake logo on many of his website’s viral posts, maybe [the Phantom of Mar-a-Lago](https://www.the-independent.com/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-elon-musk-maralago-florida-b2645385.html) and his host will never appoint someone anti-business enough to throw the hammer down soon.
Meanwhile, the conveyor belt of repackaging viral internet media and moments to advertise for a crypto casino keeps rolling. The watermarked Stake meme gets screenshotted and passed on, where it spreads through successive channels—like when publications that need to embed Twitter videos [become complicit in Stake’s amorphous campaign](https://www.dexerto.com/kick/n3on-banned-on-kick-after-guest-threatens-multiple-streamers-2954811/).
Meme creators who have [taken notice of the Stake watermarks](https://x.com/Mlickles/status/1837951358198337760) have begun parodying the campaign by [adding excessive amounts](https://x.com/NintendoGCN/status/1838308628706791660) of Stake logos to their own memes or pretending they’re instead [sponsored by Dave & Buster’s](https://x.com/M1das_OW2/status/1838263159339258265). The collective shaming [has built a grassroots rebellion](https://x.com/idiotpeach/status/1837855478145339616) but—like Community Notes—it doesn’t seem to be producing real-world effects.
Hope is not lost, though. While marketing gambling to minors across international borders might be an actual crime, it’s well understood what the real crime is in the eyes of an irony-poisoned, meme-consuming council: being cringe. As long as this public perception remains and compounds with Stake’s already shady reputation, then the brainwashing might fall flat.
